SEO.title: faq
SEO.description: Some of the most frequently asked questions about developing a JAMstack website.

FaqList.Question: Why should my site be bould with the JAMstack?

Answers.answer: Performance

Nowadays, every business and individual can benefit from a website, but a site that's clunky, slow and difficult to manage or update can do more harm than good. Users trust businesses with clean, well performing, professional websites that stand out. If websites take a 'long time' to load, long meaning 3 or more seconds, users will quickly bounce away from your site to a site that does have decent performance.

To avoid this, we can use a static site generator like Gatsby. Gatsby converts your dynamic site into static files and serves them to a CDN. Next to this Gatsby comes with smart tools like code splitting that makes your site even faster and more performant.
This results in some of the fastest sites online and often leads to load times of less than one second and a great user experience.
Security

JAMstack utilizes a serverless architecture. This means that the site is decoupled from the CMS. With other words, your site has no direct connection to the database, dependencies, user data or other sensitive information.
This way, you don't need to worry about server or database vulnerabilities.
Cost

For most projects, the hosting of static files is about ‎€0.-. That's right, most of the time hosting will be free! If that isn't enough, JAMstack sites don't require any technical maintenance since the files are static. An added benefit to this is that your site won't break either. this means no unexpected costs that can ad up. This way you will only pay to build and upgrade your site, like it should be.
SEO

JAMstack sites are optimized to be found by Google. This is because the site is static, for this reason the site will be easy to index. Combine this with the performance (Google likes good performing sites) and you will have a really solid foundation when it comes to search engine optimization.
Convenience

With a JAMstack site, you as a site owner don't have to spend any time or effort monitoring or updating plugins or other components. You don't even need to outsource this since non of these actions are required with a JAMstack site.
Another Convenience is that, just like you would be able to do with a WordPress site, you can manage your own content. This way you can tweak your site as it grows with your project.
Scalability

The JAMstack utilizes the power of React. React is a component based javascript library. What this means is that your site is very developer friendly and therefore cost effective to build upon for future expansions.
JAMstack sites have the technical capability to scale with your projects. Next to that, in the event that your site suddenly goes viral and has many active users, the CDN seamlessly compensates.
Flexibility

Their are no restrictions when it comes to what kind of content you want to display or how you want to display it to your users. There are no templates, rules or limitations that are holding back the end result of your ideal site. This way, you can realize your site exactly how you envisioned it.
Future proof

Static JAMstack sites are the way to go for a increasing amount of developers. One of the reasons for this is that a JAMstack site utilizes the most modern web technologies. The nice thing about this for you is that, In the unlikely event that something might happen where you need another developer to work on your JAMstack site, there is and will be a increasing amount of options available to take on this function.
PWA

A JAMstack site is also automatically a PWA (progressive web app). At the moment this could be seen as more of a gimmick but it hold real potential for the future. What a PWA basically means is, that your website will instantly also become a desktop app and a mobile app. That's right, with a PWA you have the capability to add your site to the home screen of your smartphone, just like you would with a regular app. With the PWA functionality, you will be able to turn your website into a mobile application.

FaqList.Question: Why shouldn't I just go for a WordPress site?

Answers.answer: WordPress is capable of amazing things in the hands of the right developer/designer. Next to that, the market has been leaning heavily towards WordPress for a long time. This has resulted in a rich plugin-eco-system and a great CMS experience.

However, WordPress does have a lot of drawbacks and restrictions. It might very well be that a solution like WordPress is fine for your project. I made a set of questions to help you in making the right decision.
1. Do you just want a simple site that doesn't need much scalability or flexibility, either now or in the future?
2. Is driving traffic to your site not a priority? I.e. You don't mind if you lose a big part of potential users and brand image because of slow load times.
3. Will you be satisfied with a site that will look like any other WordPress template site?
4. Do you not mind spending time or resources towards fixing and maintaining WordPress plugins?
5. Is or will their be any sensitive data linked to your site? (forums, users, database, etc.) If so do you want to maximize security for that data?
6. Are you willing to pay for the additional monthly/yearly fees that come with a CMS like WordPress?
If all these things don't matter for the project that you have in mind, go for it! WordPress has a great CMS and it will be able to set you up with a fully functional website.
However, if you do care about having a site that is well armed for the future, you might want to look further then the current industries 'default option'.

FaqList.Question: Are you the right choice for my site?

Answers.answer: In general the answer will be yes. However just like with any technology, the JAMstack is not perfect. Sites with a lot of content that has to update constantly would not be a great fit. A social media site would be an example of this.

I'm also more experienced in front-end development so projects with big data structures or a lot of backend code will have to be outsourced. If neither of those examples bring up any worries for your project, you're probably in the green.

If you have a large project in mind and are wondering if I'm available for longer periods of time, send me a direct message. I'm curious to find out what it is. If you still have any doubts weather the JAMstack is a good fit for your project, don't be afraid to ask.

Certainly not! I'm available to work with people all over the globe. If you are interested in letting me help you with your projects and you are not in the area of Eindhoven, do reach out. I'm curious to hear what you have in mind.

FaqList.Question: Is my site fully optimized for SEO?

Answers.answer: Yes and no. I'm a developer and a designer and I pride myself in being quite capable in both of these fields. SEO however, should be seen as something that's completely separate from these professions. As a developer, I certainly have a lot of experience with optimizing SEO, but my programming can only take your SEO performance that far.

I will make sure that you're site is technically optimized and for a lot of sites this will be more then enough to ensure your visibility on Google. But if you are looking to further optimize performance, it gets towards a more marketing oriented territory real fast.

So yes your site will technically be fully optimized for SEO, but since I'm no marketeer, there will still be a lot of room for improvements. This could be outsourced or you could do this yourself from that point.

FaqList.Question: Does my site support al browsers?

Answers.answer: Your site will support all the modern browsers. This means that your site will support all browsers except Internet explorer. Why not?

IE is discontinued since 2016. This means that is has strong limitations when it comes to the utilization of modern web technologies. Working around these limitations will drastically slow down the development process. This would be a waste of resources since new windows pc's come pre installed with it's successor Edge. Windows also advices against using IE since it is becoming increasingly vulnerable to attacks and leaks.

Luckily, the amount of users that are using IE is decreasing with each day. At the time of writing, IE usage is heading towards less then 1%. In the rare event that your user is using IE, he/she will receive a pop up message with a similar explanation.
